bestBHT.bht: In the comparison between Noah's flood and the second coming of Christ, Jesus affirms the reality of the historic flood. He warns that just as people were indifferent and unprepared during the days of Noah, many today remain unconcerned about Christ's return. He urges believers to be eager and expectant, leaving the timing and plans to God. The flood was sudden and unexpected, catching people off guard despite the warning, emphasizing the need for readiness for Christ's second coming.

Henry Alford: It is important to notice the confirmation, by His mouth who is Truth itself, of the historic reality of the flood of Noah.
This comparison also occurs in Luke xvii. 26, 27, with the addition of ‘the days of Lot’ to it.
Albert Barnes: Noe - The Greek way of writing “Noah.” See Gen. 6–9. The coming of the Son of man would be as it was in the days of Noah:
John Calvin: He wished them to be uncertain as to his coming, but yet to be prepared to expect him every day, or rather every moment.
Since indifference of this sort will exist about the time of the last day, believers ought not to indulge themselves after the example of the multitude.

And though we shall immediately find him commanding the disciples to guard against surfeiting and earthly cares, yet in this passage he does not directly condemn the intemperance, but rather the obstinacy, of those times, in consequence of which, they despised the threatenings of God, and awaited with indifference their awful destruction.
Philip Schaff: The second coming of Christ will be sudden and unexpected.
Our Lord assumes, that there was a flood sent in judgment in the days of Noah.
He endorses the history contained in the book of Genesis.
Archibald T. Robertson: Most people are either indifferent about the second coming or have fanciful schemes or programs about it.
Few are really eager and expectant and leave to God the time and the plans.
There was plenty of warning, but utter unpreparedness.
John Gill: As were the practices of the men of that generation, in which Noah lived, so will be the practices of the men of that age, in which the son of man comes.
The flood...was sudden and unexpected; it came upon men thoughtless about it, though they had warning of it.
To take vengeance on the Jews, on a sudden, at an unawares, when they would be unthoughtful about it; though they were forewarned of it by Christ and his apostles.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 24:37, Jesus confirms the historic reality of Noah's flood, comparing it to the second coming of the Son of Man. Just as people were indifferent and unprepared during the time of Noah, most people today are either indifferent or have fanciful ideas about Christ's return. However, Jesus urges believers to be eager and expectant, leaving the timing and plans to God. The flood in Noah's time was sudden and unexpected, catching people off guard despite ample warning. Similarly, the second coming of Christ will be sudden and unexpected, emphasizing the importance of staying prepared.

In the comparison between Noah's flood and the second coming of Christ, Jesus affirms the reality of the historic flood. He warns that just as people were indifferent and unprepared during the days of Noah, many today remain unconcerned about Christ's return. He urges believers to be eager and expectant, leaving the timing and plans to God. The flood was sudden and unexpected, catching people off guard despite the warning, emphasizing the need for readiness for Christ's second coming.

Jesus emphasizes the reality of Noah's flood, confirming it as a historical event. He compares the indifference and unpreparedness of people during that time to the current attitude towards His second coming. While many are apathetic or have their own ideas about it, Jesus calls for eagerness and expectancy, entrusting the timing and plans to God. The flood was unforeseen, although there was ample warning. This highlights the importance of being prepared for Christ's sudden and unexpected return.

Jesus affirms the historic reality of Noah's flood, drawing a parallel between it and his second coming. He warns that most people are indifferent or have fanciful ideas about his return, while few are truly expectant and prepared. The flood came suddenly and unexpectedly, catching people off guard despite the warning. Jesus urges believers to be watchful and ready, leaving the timing and plans to God. This comparison serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilance and preparedness for Christ's eventual return.

Jesus uses the reality of Noah's flood to emphasize the significance of his second coming. Just as people were indifferent and unprepared during the flood, many today are unconcerned or have misguided notions about Christ's return. However, Jesus urges believers to be eager and expectant, leaving the timing and plans to God. He highlights that the flood came suddenly and unexpectedly, despite the warning. This comparison stresses the importance of being ready for the unexpected and staying prepared for Christ's eventual return.
